questions.text: During the internship, as a part of your one week super speciality training, you visit the CTVS - Cardiothoracic vascular surgery department. On one of your duty days, you notice the head nurse of the department receiving the fresh sterilized supply of the following four instruments. For which of the following procedures would you be requiring these instruments?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the various cannulas used commonly during CABG - Coronary artery bypass grafting. 

Coronary Angio Bypass Graft (CABG) with Cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB):

The initiation of CPB allows the heart to be stopped. To achieve cardiac arrest, a large dose of potassium solution (cardioplegia) is injected into the coronary vessels. This requires the coronary blood flow to be completely isolated from the systemic circulation, which is done by applying a cross-clamp to the ascending aorta proximal to the aortic cannula.

There are several different delivery options for cardioplegia solutions. 

  • Retrograde cardioplegia cannula is used to administer cardioplegia solution into the coronary sinus. The self-inflating balloon distends, forming a seal only when the cardioplegia solution is administered (Image B).
  • Antegrade cardioplegia cannula is used to administer cardioplegia solution into the aortic root. The side port functions as a sump (image A).

The other cannulas used during CABG include:

  • Aortic cannula: The specially designed tip is angulated to allow the laminar flow of blood into the aortic arch (image C).
  • A dual-stage venous cannula: The first stage is the fenestrated basket that usually rests at the level of the hepatic veins and captures all venous return from the inferior vena cava. The second-stage basket is located such that it remains within the right atrium and captures venous return from the superior vena cava, azygos vein, coronary sinus, and direct collateral drainage into the right atrium.The venous drainage is a passive siphon aided by gravity (image D).

The image shows various cannulas used in CABG and the process. The indications for CABG are given in the pearl attached below.

A coronary stent placed by percutaneous coronary intervention.

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presents with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, and ptosis. He also complains of unintentional weight loss for the past month. His chest X-ray reveals a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs. He underwent the imaging modality shown, which revealed a high uptake within the tumour. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old smoker presenting with occasional chest pain, pain along the left arm, ptosis and unintentional weight loss for the past month with a chest X-ray revealing a mass at the left lung apex with the destruction of adjacent ribs and the FDG PET-CT scan shown above revealing a high uptake within the tumour is suggestive of a Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour). 

Pancoast’s tumour is a rare form of lung cancer that originates at the apex of the lung. It has a unique presentation due to the stellate ganglion, chest wall and brachial plexus involvement.

It can invade the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 commonly), resulting in a radicular distribution of pain along the ulnar nerve. Invasion of the stellate ganglion results in Horner’s syndrome which presents with ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos, and anhidrosis. Shoulder and chest pain on the same side can result from the invasion into the chest wall and the 1st and/or 2nd ribs. Local spread, if involving the trachea or esophagus can result in dyspnea or dysphagia. 

Investigations:

  • MRI > CT is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumour/ Pancoast tumour.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumour cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumours to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Management is summarized in the flowchart as shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Small cell lung carcinoma is a highly malignant tumour that has a strong link to cigarette smoking. Tumours may arise in major bronchi or in the periphery of the lung. The presence of neurosecretory granules and the expression of neuroendocrine markers, such as CD56 and chromogranin, indicate that the tumour is derived from neuroendocrine progenitor cells found in the lining of the bronchial epithelium.

Option B: Bronchial carcinoid tumours typically arise as central masses that grow into finger-like polypoid masses that frequently protrude into the bronchus lumen. They are associated with features of carcinoid syndrome like diarrhoea, flushing and wheezing. Biopsy would show clusters of neuroendocrine cells and positive chromogranin A staining.

Option D: Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumour with glandular differentiation. It originates from the terminal bronchiole and is typically found in the periphery. Tumour cells frequently "crawl" along normal-appearing alveolar septa in a lepidic pattern of spread near the tumour's periphery. 

Note:

Common symptoms of lung carcinoma include a persistent cough, weight loss, dyspnea, and non-specific chest pain. But severe localized pain suggests chest wall invasion with the infiltration of an intercostal nerve. Invasion of the apical area may involve the brachial plexus and must rise the suspicion of Pancoast’s syndrome.

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A 41-year-old man complained of unsteadiness while walking. The examination is suggestive of cerebellar disease. An MRI revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have multiple retinal hemangiomas and bilateral renal masses. Based on the histopathological image of the tumor below, what is the likely subtype of renal cell carcinoma in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with a diagnosis of Von Hippel Lindau's (VHL) disease. The image shows the presence of cells with clear cytoplasm, hence, the most likely subtype of RCC he is suffering from is the clear cell type of RCC.

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. 

Manifestations of the von Hippel-Lindau Disease:

ORGAN  

 LESION

Eye 

 Retinal hemangiomas (benign)

CNS

 Hemangioblastomas (benign)

Kidneys

Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma

Renal cyst

Adrenal glands 

 Pheochromocytoma

Pancreas 

Neuroendocrine tumours (benign and malignant)

Pancreatic cysts

Ear 

 Endolymphatic sac tumor

The most common lesions associated with VHL disease, are hemangioblastomas and typically occur in the cerebellum, spinal cord, or retina.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises most commonly from the epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. It is more common in men and is found incidentally in many patients. The common subtypes are clear-cell, papillary, and chromophobe RCC. When confined to the kidney, surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Once the disease metastasized, tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) and mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) inhibitors can be used. 

Other options-

Option (C): Papillary RCC- It exhibits various degrees of papilla formation with fibrovascular cores. The histopathological section is shown below. 

 

Option (B): Chromophobe RCC-The cells of this type have clear granular cytoplasm with distinct cell membranes. The nuclei are surrounded by halos of the clear cytoplasm. The histopathological section is shown below.

 

Option (D): Collecting duct carcinoma (Bellini duct)- arises from collecting duct cells in the medulla. Several chromosomal losses and deletions have been described, but a distinct pattern has not been identified. Histologically these tumours are characterized by malignant cells forming glands enmeshed within a prominent fibrotic stroma, typically in a medullary location.

The given image shows a pathological examination of collecting duct carcinoma-

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

Related Pearl: Familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight male patient was referred for the evaluation of renal stones. He complains of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the preferred treatment for this man?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The preferred treatment for a cystine renal calculus of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) as cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL (extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy) due to their hardness.

PCNL is the preferred treatment for -large renal stones of a diameter of more than 1.5-2.5 cm, in the presence of multiple stones, and in cases like this patient where it is a smaller, harder stone, not responsive to ESWL (like cystine, struvite, and calcium oxalate stones). 

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma, perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant, and perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track. 

Cystinuria occurs due to a hereditary defect in an amino acid transporter in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and intestine. This prevents the reabsorption of amino acids like cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. The only known complication of this disease is the formation of calculi, because of the low solubility of cystine in the urine. Cystine is more likely to precipitate in acidic urine.

Prevention of stone formation in patients with cystinuria can be done by increasing fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine with sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate. Chelating agents such as penicillamine have also been found to be useful. Tiopronin is currently the best choice drug for cystine reduction, but side effects like nephrotic syndrome may limit its long-term use. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the excretion of cystine in the urine by directly reducing its formation.

Other options-

Option (A): Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

 Option (C): Open surgery- A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. In extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated, one might resort to open/laparoscopic surgery. 

Option (D): Ureteroscopic removal- Semi-rigid ureteroscopes are frequently used to directly visualize ureteric calculi. Advances in the design of ureterorenoscopy have made it easier to access these stones by endoscopic examination.  Stones can also be fragmented using mechanical disintegration using the lithoclast. This method is generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy-

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Management of renal and ureteric calculi

ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient diagnosed with prostatic carcinoma underwent radical prostatectomy. Post-operatively he continued having symptoms of incontinence. Your team diagnoses him with a sphincter dysfunction and plans to insert the following device as shown in the image below. Where is the control pump of this device placed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) system - model 800. It is a complex device having three parts, the cuff, the balloon and the control pump. Balloon reservoirs are placed in the lower abdomen, an inflatable cuff compresses the urethra or bladder and the control pump is placed in the scrotum or labia. 

Artificial urinary sphincter system: 

In urology, this forms a part of the management of incontinence.

Indications:

  • Patients post-prostatectomy diagnosed with poor sphincter dysfunction
  • Patients with neurogenic bladder dysfunction
  • Patients with failed medical management and physiotherapy

In gynaecology, this forms a part of conservative management of stress urinary incontinence. 

Indication:

  • Patients with previous surgical failure
  • Patients with sphincteric dysfunction - secondary to perineal injuries/ trauma 
  • Patients with neurological dysfunction or neurological conditions affecting micturition 

Contra-indication: Common to both the sexes

  • Concurrent UTI/ Recurrent UTI - This is one reason why all the patients planned for management with AUS are screened for UTI.
  • Recurrent urinary strictures or diverticula
  • Small bladder or bladder with poor compliance.

The given image shows the components of the AUS implant and the fitment of the system respectively.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought by his father to his primary care physician with complaints of passing blood-coloured urine. He also complained of pain during the passage of urine and increased frequency of urination for the last 2 days.  Urine samples are negative for bacteria but contain >50 white cells and up to 10 red cells/high power microscope field. He is diagnosed with acute hemorrhagic cystitis. Which of the following is the most common viral agent causing this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of acute hemorrhagic cystitis. BK virus, a member of the polyomavirus family, is the most common virus associated with hemorrhagic cystitis.

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis is a viral urinary tract infection. It is benign and self-limited. It more commonly affects boys more than girls. It presents with cystitis and gross hematuria.

Common causes include:

  • Mycoplasma sp.
  • Herpes simplex virus.
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Adenovirus types 11, 35, 21

Treatment for viral hemorrhagic cystitis is primarily supportive, with hydration, diuresis, and bladder irrigation, although case reports of success with antiviral therapy exist. If bacterial cause is identified, it should be treated with appropriate antibiotics. 

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient came to urology OPD with incomplete voiding of urine and increased frequency of urination. After a complete workup, the urologist decided to perform a prostatectomy by Millin's approach. Which of the following indicates this approach in the given image?
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the Millin's or retropubic approach for prostate surgery.

In this approach, using a low, curved transverse suprapubic Pfannenstiel incision, the recti are split in the midline and retracted to expose the bladder. With the patient in the Trendelenburg position, the surgeon separates the bladder and the prostate from the posterior aspect of the pubis. In this approach the exposure of the inside of the prostatic cavity is good. However, this procedure is rarely performed nowadays as HOLEP (Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate) has largely superseded it. Open surgery may be performed in situations where HOLEP is not available or where diverticulectomy or the removal of large stones is required.

Other options:

Option A: 1 - Transurethral approach (TURP) is the most commonly used approach

Option C: 3 - The transvesical approach is called the Freyer approach.

Option D: 4 - The prineal approach is also called the Young's approach.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).  Post TURP, the patient on the 7th day who is normal so far suddenly collapsed on the 8th day. His body temperature is normal with a deranged heart rate and respiratory rate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a secondary haemorrhage. 

Secondary haemorrhage tends to occur after the patient has been discharged. All men should be warned about this possibility and given appropriate advice to rest and to have a high fluid intake. It is usually minor in degree but if clot retention occurs, the patient will need to be readmitted, a catheter passed and the bladder washed. 

The other complications of TURP include:

  • Retrograde ejaculation - Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). The most likely mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. 
  • Primary hemorrhage
  • Perforation of the bladder or the prostatic capsule can occur at the time of transurethral surgery
  • Sepsis due to bacteremia. They are generally caused due to indwelling catheters or chronic retention. These patients usually present with fever and profound hypotension. 
  • Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis causes erectile impotence. 
  • Overuse of coagulating diathermy following TURP causes bladder neck contracture
  • Transurethral resection of prostate (TUR) syndrome 
  • Hyponatremia secondary to TUR syndrome - which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting

TUR syndrome occurs as a complication of the TURP procedure due to the prolonged use of hypotonic irrigation fluid. Bradycardia is seen in this syndrome, not tachycardia. The incidence of this can be reduced by using isotonic glycine.

Prolonged use of hypotonic irrigation fluid, results in fluid overload, and dilutional hyponatremia causing water intoxication also known as transurethral resection (TUR) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 
  • Hypertension,
  • Pulmonary oedema
  • Bradycardia.

Management:

  • Treatment consists of fluid restriction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl child is brought with a history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Examination reveals darkening around both eyes, proptosis, and rapid jerky eye movements. There is a palpable abdominal mass with abdominal distention. Laboratory examination shows hypokalemia. The mass is excised and histopathological examination shows a small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of neuroblastoma. The child presents with abdominal pain and a mass. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic Homer-Wright pseudorosettes which point towards the diagnosis. The diarrhoea, hypokalemia and ocular features in this patient are a result of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this condition. This tumor arises from the adrenal glands and urinary catecholamines may be used to diagnose and monitor this tumour.

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumours in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. There has been an association established with fetal alcohol syndrome, neurofibromatosis, fetal hydantoin syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.

Genetics - Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The N-MYC gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favourable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Clinical features:

Approximately two-thirds of the cases arise in the abdomen and most of these cases arise from the adrenal glands. Other sites include the organs of ZuckerKandl, posterior mediastinum, pelvis, head, and neck. 

The symptoms associated with this condition are -

  • abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
  • Pain - abdominal pain or localized back pain or bone pain
  • constipation
  • proptosis
  • periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbital metastases)
  • Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis)
  • weakness (from spinal cord compression)
  • scoliosis
  • bladder dysfunction
  • palpable non-tender subcutaneous blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • secretory diarrhea (from paraneoplastic production of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide [VIP])
  • systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss)
  • anemia
  • heterochromia iridis (different colors of the iris or portions of the iris)
  • hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines
  • unilateral nasal obstruction

Paraneoplastic syndrome:

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome - It occurs in about 1-3% of patients with neuroblastoma. The characteristics symptoms are rapid, dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking (myoclonus) involving limbs or trunk, and/or ataxia.
  • Secretion of VIP - It causes abdominal distention and intractable secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia. Serum VIP levels will be >75 pg/ml

Classification: Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

Diagnosis:

  • Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. A biopsy will show the presence of small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.
  • Other investigations that would aid in the diagnosis include CBC, urinary catecholamine excretion, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, nuclear imaging with an I-131 MIBG scan, and CT to detect metastasis.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor, chemotherapy, and radiation. The tumors which have spread to other places will require surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Important chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, cyclophosphamide, topotecan, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and etoposide. 

An image of histopathology of neuroblastoma is shown below.

 

Nephroblastoma:

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs. On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Rhabdoid tumour of the kidney:

Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney is the most aggressive and lethal childhood renal tumor and accounts for 2% of renal tumors.

Rhabdomyosarcoma:

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the most common soft tissue tumor. The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests Rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) generally. But, the histopathology would show elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle different stages of embryogenesis with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of RMS

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into 4 major subtypes

    1. Embryonal: Makes up 80% of orbital rhabdomyosarcomas and presents most commonly in young children (mean age 7-8)
    2. Alveolar subtype exhibits small, round, densely appearing cells that are loosely arranged, with septae that are similar to the alveoli of the lung; carries the worst prognosis
    3. Botryoid - variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; subepithelial grape-like aggregates of tumor cells; seen most commonly in infants.
    4. Pleomorphic

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin and myoglobin

Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and hematogenous and lymphatic metastase

 

Note:

Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extracranial) solid tumor of childhood.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on computed tomography (CT), but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented to the casualty following 2 episodes of haematemesis and is currently hypotensive. The surgery resident on duty tries to control the bleeding with the instrument shown below. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding. Temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades. The above image shows the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube.

It has 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are:

  • Gastric balloon port
  • Esophageal balloon port
  • Gastric aspiration port

The gastric balloon is inflated and tension is applied to the gastroesophageal junction. If this does not control the haemorrhage, the esophageal balloon is inflated as well, compressing the venous plexus between them. Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Option A: The Minnesota tube has 4 openings:

  • Two suction tubes:
    • Gastric aspiration port
    • Esophageal aspiration port
  • Two inflation tubes:
    • Gastric balloon port
    • Oesophageal balloon port

This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

The image below depicts the Minnesota tube. 

Option C: Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. 

Option D: Ewald's tube is generally used for gastric lavage. It has only one aspiration port for the stomach.

The protocol for the management of oesophageal varices is given below.

questions.text: In your university practical exams, the external examiner displays the following retractors on the desk and asks you to pick the Deaver's retractor. What would you pick?
questions.solution:
If you were asked to pick Deaver's retractor you would pick the instrument labeled '1'.

The given image shows

1 - Deaver's retractor

2 - Doyen's retractor

3 - Morris retractor

4 - Czerny's retractor

Deaver’s retractor: It is used to retract the liver, spleen, and other abdominal viscera. It is atraumatic and gives adequate exposure of the surgical field.

 

Doyen's retractor: It is used in pelvic surgeries.

 

Morris retractor: It is used to retract the abdominal wall.

 

Czerny's retractor: It is used in surgeries like hernia, and laparotomy, especially during closure.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for circumcision under daycare surgery. Which of the following is not a requirement for a successful daycare surgery?

choices.text: Patient's age is more important than physiological status

questions.solution:
The physiological status of a patient is a more important determinant than their chronological age during daycare surgery. Thus, the opposite, as mentioned in option (B) is not an essential requirement for a successful daycare surgery. 

A surgical procedure can be considered as daycare surgery when the patient's admission, procedure, and discharge all take place within the span of 12 working hours. In these procedures, the patient does not have to stay overnight at the hospital. 

Minimal tissue handling during the procedure (Option D), achieving good hemostasis (Option B), and using minimally invasive techniques (Option A) are all factors that can help to achieve a successful daycare surgery. 

Physical fitness for the procedure, short duration, and a home environment that can support recovery and postoperative care are all important factors when choosing daycare surgery for a patient.

When selecting a patient it is important to consider the following-

  • Medically, the physiological health of the patient is of greater importance than their chronological age. For short procedures, the current health status will help us decide if the patient will tolerate the procedure or not. Chronological age becomes more important for longer, more invasive surgeries. 
  • Surgically, the procedure should ideally last less than 2 hours, and the patient should be able to consume liquids and possibly some solid food by the time they get discharged on the same day. 
  • Socially, it is important to identify a designated caregiver for the patient at least for the first 24 hours after surgery. Their home should also have the facilities to support their recovery and they should be sent home with all the sites required for their post-operative care. 

Some procedures that qualify for daycare surgery are listed below-

  • Arthroscopies
  • Biopsy (temporal, lymph node)
  • Reducing a strangulated hernia
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess 
  • K-wiring of a finger or wrist bone fracture
  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy

Patient's having daycare surgery can usually be discharged when they have stable vitals, have adequately controlled pain with a prescription for further pain management at home, can perform basic activities on their own, have no evidence of incision site bleeding, have a designated caregiver, and have all the instructions required for further management at home and instructions in case of an emergency.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the surgical modality shown in the image below?
  1. This new modality was for the first time used to take a brain biopsy.
  2. It evolves from computer-integrated surgery
  3. In comparison to laparoscopic or other minimal access surgeries, these have a two-fold increased advantage over them
  4. The advantage of this system is that it eliminates hand tremors allowing greater precision
  5. The use of this system makes the working ambient environment ergonomic
questions.solution:
The given image shows robot-assisted surgery. All the statements are true.

Robotic surgery:

  • This new modality was for the first time used to take a brain biopsy in the year 1985. 
  • It evolves from computer-integrated surgery where mechanical hands through computer integrated software can work like surgeon's hands. 
  • In comparison to laparoscopic or other minimal access surgeries, these have a two-fold increased advantage over them
  • The advantages for the surgeon include better visualisation (higher magnification) with stereoscopic views; elimination of hand tremor allowing greater precision; improved manoeuvring as a result of the ‘robotic wrist’, which in some systems allows up to seven degrees of freedom; and the fact that large external movements of the surgical hands can be scaled down and transformed to limited internal movements of the ‘robotic hands’, extending the surgical ability to perform complex procedures in limited space. 
  • The use of this system makes the working ambient environment ergonomic. Less stress makes better output from the surgeon. 
  • In the current era, however, these devices seem most often applied in pelvic surgery (typically urology, colorectal, and gynecology) within in-house operating. 

One major operative barrier to adoption remains the prohibitive costs for many healthcare environments

Limitations of minimal access surgery

  • Reliance on remote vision and operation
  • Loss of tactile feedback
  • Dependence on hand-eye coordination
  • Difficulty with haemostasis
  • Reliance on new techniques
  • Extraction of large specimens

questions.text:
The given image shows a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) of a 3-year-old boy who was diagnosed with hydronephrosis. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
  1. It is the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children
  2. The valves are membranes that typically lie just distal to the verumontanum
  3. The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole sign and is the investigation of choice. 
  4. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction
  5. Prenatal decompression of urinary bladder is done to avoid pulmonary hypoplasia
questions.solution:
The given image shows a dilated prostatic urethra and transverse filling defects corresponding with the valves. So, the MCU is consistent with posterior urethral valves. Statements 1, 2, 4, 5 are true. 

The posterior urethral valve affects only males and MCU is the investigation of choice. 

Posterior urethral valves: 

Features:

  • Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of severe obstructive uropathy in children.
  • The valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit within them, which typically lie just distal to the verumontanum
  • They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow. A urethral catheter can be passed retrogradely.
  • 15% of boys with posterior urethral valves have unilateral reflux into a nonfunctioning dysplastic kidney, termed the VURD syndrome (valves, unilateral reflux, dysplasia)
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder
  • Antenatal USG would also demonstrate oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then babies typically present with urinary infection in the neonatal period or with uraemia and renal failure
  • Clinically a poor urinary stream, dribbling and palpable bladder (due to diverticula) can be present.
  • The investigation of choice is micturating cystourethrography
  • The ultrasound shows the typical 'key-hole sign in which the bladder and the proximal urethra is dilated
  • Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with continuing lifelong supportive treatment of the dilated urinary tract, recurrent urinary infections and uraemia. 

The given image below shows the 'key-hole sign.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with sudden pain in his scrotum associated with fever. His condition rapidly progressed and his scrotum appears as below. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for which he is taking canagliflozin. IV fluids are started and vital signs are noted to be stable. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image findings of cellulitis of the testis are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. The next best step in the management of this condition is IV fluids, intravenous antibiotics, and urgent surgical excision.

Fournier's gangrene - 

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. 

Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as

  • HIV
  • Alcoholism
  • Diabetes (the SGLT-2 inhibitors currently available are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin which can also cause Fournier's Gangrene)

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus can be seen as shown in the image below.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, it is also called shameful exposure of the testis. It is a surgical emergency.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. When the infection has been controlled, the vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man with a known case of sickle cell disease presented with sustained painful penile erection for the last 5 hours. Blood gas analysis from the penis shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Aspiration of the sludge of blood and intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine failed to produce a response. What should be the next best line of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette in this patient is suggestive of ischemic priapism secondary to sickle cell disease and the next best line of management among the given options is to perform Quackel's shunt. It is a proximal shunt between corpora cavernosa and spongiosum. 

Priapism refers to a persistent erection lasting >4 hours, not related to sexual stimulation. There are two types of priapism:

  • Ischemic -more common
  • Non-ischemic

Ischaemic priapism occurs due to venous congestion, and consequent thrombosis. On examination, the penis is tender. Blood gas analysis of penile blood shows hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidosis. Risk factors for priapism are sickle cell disease or trait, malignancy, medications, cocaine abuse, and total parenteral nutrition.

Detumescence should be ensured in 6-12 hours to avoid progressive, irreversible damage to the corpus cavernosal tissue with subsequent fibrosis and erectile dysfunction. Initial management can be done with oral agents like pseudoephedrine or baclofen.

  • First-line treatment- Aspiration of the sludged blood in the corpora cavernosa
    • By insertion of a large 18-gauge needle into the lateral aspect of one corporal body 
  • Intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine (an alpha-adrenoceptor agonist) is the next line of therapy.
  • Surgical shunts
    • Distal shunts like Winter shunt (in the emergency room), Al-Ghorab shunt (operative shunt)
    • Proximal shunts like Quackel shunt (proximal cavernosum-spongiosum), Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein)

For those with sickle cell disease, hydration and oxygen administration should be performed first. 

Non-ischemic priapism usually occurs after blunt perineal trauma. A fistula develops between the central penile artery and the sinusoidal space, leading to a persistent, painless erection. Blood gas analysis shows characteristics of arterial blood. Treatment is not an emergency and is done by selective arterial embolization. (option D)

Other options:

Options A and B- Glansectomy and penectomy are generally performed for penile carcinoma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old anxious male comes to the urology OPD with a chronic history of deformity of the penis and pain on erection. He is subjected to the USG of the penis, the findings of which are as shown below. Which of the following associated is not a part of the classical Galezia's triad expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the penile calcifications of the corpus cavernosum. Erectile dysfunction is a complication of Peyronie's disease and not a component of Galezia's triad.

Galezia triad conisits of:

  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Dupuytren's contracture 
  • Peyronie's disease

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

The active phase is characterized by changes in penile curvature or deformity and pain with erection. Stable disease is characterized by the absence of pain and nonprogression of deformity. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical examination but MRI may be helpful.

Verapamil intralesional drug therapy and collagenase clostridium histolyticum (CCH) intralesional drug therapy are safe and well tolerated treatment options. Penile traction therapy, usually in conjunction with medical management, has shown some efficacy.

In severe deformity and calcifications, surgical options are preferred. Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend increases during the active phase (18-24 months).  The treatment will shorten the erect penile length.

The image below depicts the pathology of Peyronie's disease:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is incorrect about retractile testes?
  1. The scrotum with retractile testis is abnormal
  2. They are more common than true undescended testes
  3. Ectopic testes is a differential of retractile testes
  4. Chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis
  5. Retractile testes may require orchidopexy
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 5 are incorrect, as retractile testes require no treatment, and the scrotum is generally normal. 

A retractile testis is a normally developed and descended testis that retracts back into the inguinal canal due to hyper reflexive cremasteric muscle contraction. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal. They are more common than true undescended testes. The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal.

Therefore, any stimulation of the skin of the scrotum or thigh causes the testis to ascend and temporarily disappear into the inguinal canal. When the cremaster relaxes, the testis reappears in the scrotum.

The scrotum of a boy with such a retractile testis is normal (normal rugosity is seen).

Retractile testes require no treatment. 

Note: The chair test helps to differentiate retractile testis from ectopic testis because both of them describe a condition wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

Chair Test:  Here, The young patient is asked to sit on a chair, hugging his knees to his chest. This maneuver helps the retractile testis to get pushed down back to the bottom of the scrotum. By this test, the retractile testis can be differentiated from the ectopic testis.

Remember:

Ectopic testis must be differentiated from retractile testis, both of which describe conditions wherein the testis lies in an abnormal position. 

The ectopic testis is present outside the usual path of descent from the abdomen to the scrotum. Some of the ectopic sites include the femoral triangle, the root of the penis, and the perineum. However, a retractile testis is present in the scrotum and occasionally jumps to lie in the inguinal canal. 

An ectopic testis is usually treated with orchidopexy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal mass.  On examination, the mass was firm, non-tender and it was possible to get above it. His past history was significant for undescended testes, treated surgically. Ultrasonography showed a homogenous mass, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes. After confirmation of the diagnosis, the mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. The surgeon is also suspecting metastases. Which of the following is the most common route of metastases seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical case points to a diagnosis of seminoma which is the commonest testicular tumor in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. Seminomas metastasize mainly via the lymphatics and hematogenous spread is uncommon.

The lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes near the origin of the gonadal vessels. The contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes are sometimes involved by tumor spread, but the inguinal lymph nodes are affected only if the scrotal skin is involved.

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT) (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade.
  • It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma.
  • The gross specimen (image below) shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis
  • Histopathological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. 
  • Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP), and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.
  • It usually presents as painless testicular enlargement. A heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Else it is found on USG examination. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.
  • Sonography is mandatorily done in all suspected cases. Tumor markers which may be elevated in up to 50% of cases, should be investigated prior to orchiectomy. This serves as useful in follow-up after surgery.
  • An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment. Surveillance using CT imaging and tumor marker to look for metastasis or relapse is done. Histopathologic diagnosis also helps to plan radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

The USG image shows a mass that is homogenous, hypoechoic compared to surrounding stroma, and arising from within testes. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text:
A patient with a family history of prostatic cancer is suffering from metastatic, castrate/hormone-resistant prostatic cancer. He had read online about the Sipuleucel-T vaccine for prostatic carcinoma. He wants to get some opinion about the vaccine. Which of the following information regarding the vaccine is true?
  1. It is an autologous cellular immunotherapy
  2. It is a prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)-loaded dendritic cell vaccine. 
  3. It contains a minimum of 50 million autologous CD54+ cells activated with PAP
  4. The recommended course of therapy for the vaccine is 3 complete doses, given at approximately 2-week intervals
  5. Patients should not be premedicated orally with acetaminophen or antihistamines
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, 3, 4 are true regarding the Sipuleucel-T vaccine. 

  • It is an autologous cellular immunotherapy
  • It is a prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)-loaded dendritic cell vaccine. 
  • It contains a minimum of 50 million autologous CD54+ cells activated with PAP
  • It is indicated for the treatment of asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic metastatic castrate resistant (hormone refractory) prostate cancer.
  • The recommended course of therapy for the vaccine is 3 complete doses, given at approximately 2-week intervals
  • Patients should be premedicated orally with acetaminophen and antihistamines like diphenhydramine
  • The vaccine is generally administered as IV infusion with no cell filters attached
  • Complications include acute infusion reactions (reported within 1 day of infusion) resulting in fever, chills, respiratory events (dyspnea, hypoxia, and bronchospasm), nausea, vomiting, fatigue, hypertension, and tachycardia.

Several immunological strategies are under clinical development to combat prostate cancer. The most important of these include sipuleucel-T (Provenge), the autologous prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)-loaded dendritic cell vaccine; the GVAX allogeneic recombinant whole-cell vaccine and cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) inhibitor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with hypertension presents to the emergency room with severe loin pain and urinary complaints. The patient also gives an occasional history of passing green-blue color urine.  After an ultrasound of the kidney, ureter, and urinary bladder, he was diagnosed with renal stones and was posted for percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). While documenting the drug history,  which of the following drugs should you specifically probe in for?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient is diagnosed with renal stones and is posted for percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). Drug history of triamterene should be probed for as it is a urolithogenic drug.

Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic used as an antihypertensive agent. Triamterene can crystallize in the urine resulting in stones composed of the drug itself. However, it has a greater tendency to get incorporated into existing renal stones. Triamterene is also associated with an occasional history of passing green-blue-colored urine.

Urolithogenic drugs are those that promote urinary stone formations. These drugs either precipitate the compounds or inhibit certain inhibitors of this precipitation process thereby accentuating the process of stone formation.  

Common urolithogenic drugs are:

  • Antihypertensive:
    • Furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics)
    • Triamterene (potassium-sparing diuretic)
  • Decongestant: Ephedrine
  • Expectorant: Guaifenesin
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide
  • Antiretroviral agents:
    • Indinavir (highest incidence)
    • Lopinavir-ritonavir
    • Ritonavir-boosted atazanavir
    • Nelfinavir
    • Amprenavir

questions.text:
Identify the correctly matched image showing clinical findings and the corresponding clinical class to which it belongs to under the 2020 revised CEAP classification of varicose ulcer.

CEAP: Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correctly matched clinical finding with the corresponding clinical class as per the revised CEAP guidelines is B - Atrophie blanche (C4b).

Image A - shows tortuous dilated veins - C2

Image B - Atrophie blanche(C4b)  - localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease. Lipodermatosclerosis(C4b) is also under the same class. It is due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis leading to a tight, contracted, 'woody' leg. Can lead to contractures over the Achilles tendon and is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

Image C - fan-shaped telangiectasia over ankle or foot is characteristic of corona phlebectatica which is classified as C4c under CEAP guidelines.

Image D - Shows venous ulcer with active crusts falling under healing venous ulcer classified as C5.

Varicose veins - are tortuous dilatation of veins due to venous insufficiency. It commonly presents as lower limb swelling with a sensation of heaviness, burning, and aching over the affected area or whole limb.

Diagnosis is majorly done using duplex ultrasound and very rarely involves MR venography or intravenous ultrasound(IVUS).

Treatment is achieved using modalities such as compression, laser ablation, endothermal ablation, radiofrequency ablation, endovenous glue, ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy, open surgery, etc. 

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes the following changes -

  1. C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  2. C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  3. C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

En

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Superficial

Ad

Deep

Ap

An

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn
