Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle, 7 days after her knee replacement surgery. On examination, her heart rate is 70 beats per min, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her SPO2 is 96% on room air. The test shown below is positive. She has no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis. Calculate her modified Well's score for the risk of developing pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis(DVT). The most common clinical presentation of DVT is pain and tenderness in the calf. The given image shows the method of eliciting Moses' sign, which is calf pain/tenderness on applying direct pressure over calf muscles seen in deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The Well's score in this patient is 7.5

In such patients who fall in the high-risk category, a combination of mechanical and pharmacological treatment with heparin should be initiated. 

Calculation of Modified Well's score in this case:

  • Signs and symptoms of DVT = 3
  • No alternative diagnosis = 3
  • Heart rate is 70 beats per min. (<100) = 0
  • Surgery in previous 4 weeks = 1.5
  • No previous PE = 0
  • No hemoptysis = 0
  • No cancer (no significant weight loss) = 0

Total score = 7.5

Modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely >4
  • PE unlikely <or =4

Well's criteria (Three-tiered clinical probability assessment):

  • High risk >6
  • Moderate risk 2-6
  • Low risk <2

DVT is mostly unilateral, with an unreliable clinical examination. Some cases may present directly as pulmonary thromboembolism.

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s sign
  • Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Mose's sign- Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses’ sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Treatment

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Pulmonary embolism is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

 

 

 

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you notice a child with peculiar eye movements as shown in the gif below. Which of the following can be the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome(OMS)  is seen in the case of neuroblastoma.

It is rapid, conjugate eye nystagmus with involuntary spasms of the limbs also called dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome.The causes include:

When opsoclonus and myoclonus occur together, the cause is a tumour until proven otherwise.In other cases, the disorder has been designated ‘idiopathic’ or attributed to various mostly viral infections. 

Most patients do not have antineuronal antibodies. A small subset of patients with ataxia, opsoclonus, and other eye-movement disorders develop anti-Ri antibodies. Both these could be secondary to viral infections or encephalitis. 

The main treatment for OMS is early and sufficient immunotherapy with the goal of gaining a durable complete neurological remission. The general line of management includes corticosteroid administration or ACTH. If a tumour is present, surgical resection is standard. 

Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. It is the most common extracranial solid tumour in childhood. At the same time, brain tumour is the most common solid tumour in childhood. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­ fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including the adrenal medulla, paraspinal sympathetic ganglia, and sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl.

It is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour-associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT of the head is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp: 101 F, BP: 120/88 mmHg, and pupils are reactive. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?
  1. Hess and Hunt's scale is used to grade the severity of this condition
  2. Most common spontaneous cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm.
  3. Nifedipine is recommended for all patients with this condition.
  4. Triple H therapy is used which includes hypothermia, hypertension and hypervolemia.
  5. The treatment of choice is surgical clipping.
questions.solution:
These patient's clinical features are suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). CT reveals blood in the cistern. Combined with clinical manifestations of severe headache, neck rigidity, and absent focal neurological defect, the most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space. This is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH:

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

Clinically presents as a thunderclap headache, neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness, no focal neurological deficit. SAH can mostly present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

A painful third nerve palsy is typically the result of compression from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intraocular hemorrhages, classically subhyaloid, may be visible on fundoscopy. The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson’s Syndrome. 

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head, lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia. Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the CSF withdrawn. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern. CT angiography has a high sensitivity for aneurysms and AVMs, but digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.

The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.  Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

In patients with symptomatic vasospasm, triple H therapy is added as part of the therapeutic regimen. It does not include hypothermia. 

  • Induced hypertension- with vasopressors to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
  • Hypervolemia- to maintain the circulatory blood volume 
  • Hemodilution- accompanying change due to fluid therapy.

Hess and Hunt's scale is the most widely used scale to the grade of severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Grade Description
1 Asymptomatic or minimal headache and slight nuchal rigidity
2 Moderate to severe headache, nuchal rigidity, cranial nerve palsy only
3 Drowsy, confusion, or mild focal deficit
4 Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity
5 Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity, moribund appearance

The World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading of subarachnoid hemorrhage considers two parameters:

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Presence or absence of focal neurological deficit(in the form of dysphasia/limb weakness).

WFNS grading is as follows:

Grade Glasgow Coma Scale Focal deficits
I 15 –
II 13–14 –
III 13–14 +
IV 7–12 ±
V 3–6 ±

The given image shows CSF xanthochromia.

questions.text: What procedure is being done?
questions.solution:
• The procedure that is shown is VATS- Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery.
  • Many thoracic procedures can be done through VATS like pneumonectomy, lobectomy, empyema drainage, pleural biopsy and pleurodesis.
  • The patient is usually positioned with the disease side uppermost, having had a double lumen endotracheobronchial tube placed by the anaesthetist to allow for single-lung ventilation.
  • Lung biopsy and the treatment of recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications.
  • The principal advantage is that a large incision is avoided resulting in less postoperative pain and a more rapid recovery.

SILS- Single Incision Laparoscopic Surgery

NOTES- Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery

questions.text: A 40-year-old male sustained a road traffic accident and had gross hematuria. He was shifted to the emergency department in the nearby hospital. His BP was 70/30 mm of Hg and his pulse was 130/min at the time of admission. Initial fluid resuscitation was done and BP normalized. On clinical examination, there was some abrasion on the abdomen in the right iliac and lumbar region. Contrast enhanced CT  shows the right renal injury with urinary extravasation and injury to the right renal artery with a contained hemorrhage. What is the grade of this renal injury according to the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) kidney injury scale?
questions.solution:
Renal injury with urinary extravasation and injury to the right renal artery belongs to grade 4.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. 

It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.

Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

questions.text: Reflux of urine into the renal pelvis, calyces with moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces, indicates __________  vesicoureteric reflux.
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into the renal pelvis, calyces with moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces, indicates grade 4 vesicoureteral reflux.

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is a micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE                                      DESCRIPTION
              I Reflux into a nondilated ureter
             II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation
             III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
             IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
              V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyces; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy. What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.solution:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.

Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.

Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion’s disease?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder
Hypertrophy of the external sphincter of the bladder
Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethra

questions.solution:
Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion’s disease. This leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Its clinical features include voiding and storage symptoms (usually associated with BPH). Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate:

  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Dribbling of urine
  • Hesitancy
  • Intermittent stream
  • Nocturia

It is commonly seen in young patients.

Bladder outlet obstruction can occur due to 2 causes:

  • Muscular causes
    • Congenital hypertrophy of internal sphincter, i.e., Marion's disease
    • Dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia)
  • Fibrosis of bladder neck following transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)

questions.text: Identify the pathological finding indicated by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Structures represented by the one marked by the arrow are identified as corpora amylacea.

They are tiny calcified lamellated bodies found in the glandular alveoli of elderly men. 

It is hypothesized that they are the fore-runners of prostatic caliculi.

questions.text: I-VITROS in relation to minimal access surgery is?

choices.text: Insufflate, Visualise, Identify, Triangulate, Retract, Operate, Seal
Identify, Visualise, Incise, Triangulate, Repair, Observe, Seal
Insufflate, View, Incise, Triangulate, Retract, Observe, Seal
Identify,  Visualise, Incise, Trinagulate, Repair, Operate, Seal

questions.solution:
I-VITROS refers to the core principles of minimal acces surgery and is summarized as:

  • I - Insufflate
  • V - Visualise
  • I - Identify
  • T - Triangulate
  • R - Retract
  • O - Operate
  • S - Seal

Minimal access surgery is a product of modern technology and surgical innovation that aims to accomplish surgical therapeutic goals with minimum somatic and psychological trauma.

Examples include: Laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, endoluminal endoscopy,  perivisceral endoscopy, arthroscopy and intra articular joint surgery.

Advantages of minimal access surgeries:

  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding
  • herniation and nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved vision

Limitations of minimal access surgery :

  • Reliance on remote vision and operating
  • Loss of tactile feedback
  • Dependence on hand–eye coordination
  • Difficulty with haemostasis
  • Reliance on new techniques
  • Extraction of large specimens

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Veress needle is used to produce pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery. 

A blunt trocar is passed through the sharp needle.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Since the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or a penetrating towel clip to elevate it away from the underlying structures. 

Option A: An aneurysm needle (shown below) is used to catch small vessels and nerves.

Option C: Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheostomy open.

Option D: Urethral dilator is used to dilate urethra.

questions.text: Which of the following IV cannulae are preferably used in pediatric patients?

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the device shown below?

choices.text: Spores of bacillus stearothermophilus act as control
Holding period 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a hot air oven. Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control in a hot air oven.

Hot air oven:

  • It is a method of sterilization by dry heat.
  • Holding period of 160°C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, swabs, glass syringes, scalpel, forceps, scissors.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery – 2 hours at 150°C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control.

Autoclave machine:

  • Sterilization by moist heat.
  • High penetrative power
  • Temperature - 121°C for 15 min
  • Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus acts as a control.

Autoclave machine is shown above.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of a blow to the perineum, blood at the tip of the meatus, swelling of the penis and scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the bulbar urethra.

Urethral injuries can be classified into:

 Type Proximal urethral injury Distal urethral injury
Site of injury
  • Prostatic urethra
  • Membranous urethra
  • Bulbar urethra
  • Penile urethra
Mechanism Secondary to pelvic fracture

Occurs due to a blow to the perineum by:

  • Straddle injury
  • Loose manhole covering
  • Gymnasium accidents
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Deep perineal hematoma
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Perineal hematoma (butterfly hematoma)


Note: Urinary bladder rupture occurs due to an injury to the suprapubic region. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is more common and associated with pelvic fracture. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on a distended bladder. It manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope.

questions.text: Paradoxical incontinence is seen in:
questions.solution:
Paradoxical incontinence occurs in an ectopic ureter.

In females, an ectopic ureter opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. A woman who voids normally but who has dribbled urine for as long as she can remember, probably has an ectopic ureteral orifice. This is paradoxical incontinence.

questions.text: All are true regarding circumcision except _____.

choices.text: Hemorrhage due to bleeding from frenular artery

questions.solution:
Circumcision is often performed in the neonatal period, infancy, or childhood for cultural or religious reasons and is also performed after the newborn period, when phimosis, paraphimosis, balanoposthitis, or when sexually transmitted diseases are more prevalent. It does not increase the sexual drive.

Medical benefits of circumcision:

  • Reduced urinary infections in infancy
  • Decreased incidence of sexually transmitted disease
  • Marked reduction in the incidence of penile carcinoma

Complications of circumcision:

  • Bleeding is the most frequent complication and occurs in approximately 0.1% of cases.
  • Most infections are minor and superficial, manifested by redness and occasionally purulence at the circumcision site that usually responds to local wound care.
  • A common complication of neonatal circumcision is meatal stenosis, probably produced by a chemical meatitis from ammoniacal urine exposure on the tip of the penis while the patient is still wearing diapers.
  • Serious complications are rare but include recurrent phimosis, wound separation, major tissue loss, concealed penis, skin bridges between the shaft and the glans, inclusion cysts, urethrocutaneous fistula, and loss of some of the glans or, extremely rarely, all of the penis.

Contraindications for circumcision:

  • prematurity
  • anomalies of the penis (like chordee, or curvature of the penis)
  • hypospadias
  • epispadias
  • concealed or buried penis
  • micropenis
  • webbed penis
  • ambiguous genitalia

Bleeding diatheses are not absolute contraindications for circumcision, but it should be avoided in these cases.

questions.text: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following is the first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?
questions.solution:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.

It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.

Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).

The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with unilateral scrotal swelling. On examination, the swelling shows transillumination and the testis is palpable separate from the swelling. The fluid aspirated from the swelling resembles barley water in appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a unilateral scrotal swelling, which shows transillumination, and fluid aspirated from the swelling showing a barley water appearance is suggestive of a spermatocele.

A spermatocele is an unilocular retention cyst derived from the epididymis. It is a cystic lesion that transilluminates. When aspirated, the fluid has a characteristic barley water appearance due to the presence of spermatozoa.

Transillumination can be present in swelling caused by spermatoceles or an epididymal cyst. Differences between a spermatocele and an epididymal cyst are demonstrated in the table below:

Spermatocele Epididymal cyst
Unilocular retention cyst Multiple, multilocular (bunch of grapes on palpation)

Present at the epididymal head, above and behind the upper pole of testes

 Posterior to testis
Barley water fluid appearance on aspiration Aspiration is usually ineffective as the cyst is multilocular
Treatment: Excision Treatment: Excision


Hydrocele is a scrotal swelling caused by the accumulation of serous fluid in the processus vaginalis. Clinically, a hydrocele encloses the testis and the epididymis. Hence, the testis will not be palpable separately from the swelling.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy present’s to the Emergency with complaints of pain on the right side of his scrotum for the past half an hour. History reveals trauma with a cricket ball. On examination, it is found that the right-sided testes is positioned high and the left testes is found to lie horizontally. The sign shown by the right and left testes are respectively:-
questions.solution:
Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle and the twisting of the cord cause the affected testis to be positioned higher


Angell’s sign: The testis on the opposite side lies horizontally because of the bilaterality of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.


Prehn’s Sign is used to differentiate the torsion of testes from acute epididymo orchitis. In the case of acute epididymo orchitis, the pain gets relieved on the elevation of the testis but not in torsion of testes

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD with a constellation of features such as impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of femoral pulses. The image below shows the findings seen in the leg. In which of the following conditions are the patient's features seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome.

Leriche syndrome is a rare form of aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD) that presents with the triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses.

Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery causes claudication of the buttock or thigh. Absent distal pulses, bruit over the aortoiliac region, and associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen.

Investigations that are useful include Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, ankle-brachial pressure index, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA).

Management is by exercise, smoking cessation, control of diabetes, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as HMG CoA reductase inhibitors and 75 mg of clopidogrel or aspirin should be given. Transluminal angioplasty and stenting are useful.

The other options are sound-alike signs/syndromes.

Lemmel syndrome: This is obstructive jaundice caused by a periampullary duodenal diverticulum compressing the intrapancreatic part of the common bile duct, with resultant upstream dilatation of the extra- and intrahepatic bile ducts.

Lhermitte sign: This refers to shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.

Lemierre syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of an oropharyngeal infection. The organism involved is typically a fusiform bacillus. The condition presents with severe neck pain, septicemia, or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with an infection of the upper aerodigestive tract.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: The uterine artery crosses the ureter ______
questions.solution: The uterine artery crosses the ureter anteriorly (Water under the bridge). Damage to the ureter is more likely at this site (most dangerous site) during hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers rarely metastasizes to the liver?
questions.solution:
Prostate cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastatic lesions.  The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination through the portal venous system.  The most relevant metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after complete resection.

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text:
Lab values from a routine workup done for a hypertensive man are given below. Further investigations revealed hepatosplenomegaly with a 5.5 cm tumor arising from the right kidney. No signs of metastasis were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Total bilirubin = 3.1 mg/dl

ALP = 230 U/L

Albumin = 2.8mg/dl

Prothrombin time = 16.2 sec

Hypergammaglobulinemia
questions.solution:
The given scenario points to a diagnosis of Stauffer syndrome in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. 

Stauffer syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. It is a non-metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6. It is characterized by the presence of hepatosplenomegaly with no features of metastasis and the following lab findings:

  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Raised ALP
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Hypergammaglobulinemia
  • Prolonged prothrombin time

Option A: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to the development of renal failure in patients with advanced chronic liver disease.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction (HVOTO).

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp and face is suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is most commonly involved.

Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long-standing non-pitting edema in the limbs.

Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues.

Lymphedema can be primary or secondary.

Primary lymphedema includes: 

  • Lymphedema congenita (0-2 years): more common in males, involves multiple limbs, face, and genitalia. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Nonne Milroy syndrome.
  • Lymphedema praecox (2-35 years): more common in females, the most common type of primary lymphedema with a peak incidence in puberty. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Meig's disease.
  • Lymphedema tarda (>35 years): Rare and uncommon.

Secondary lymphedema is more common than primary and is the most common cause of lymphedema overall. Causes include lymph node dissection (axillary or inguinal), post-mastectomy, postoperative radiotherapy, obesity, varicose vein surgery, and trauma.

Complications of lymphedema include infections, skin changes, recurent cellulitis, non-healing ulcers, and lymphangiosarcoma.

Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, and external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be considered.

questions.text: Identify the device given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chemoport.

Chemoports are implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used access veins for port placement. These devices are usually retained for a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

questions.text: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. 

NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.
